dynamic_line: I suppose I can trust you that much.  What do you want to know?

responses.text: How did you come to power here?
When did you build this place?

dynamic_line: I was a big history buff back then, but I worked in dead-end accounting for U Amherst to cover my degree.  I had three friends who I hung with after-hours; we were out on the town when <the_cataclysm> came.

responses.text: When did you build this place?
I'd like to ask you about something else.

dynamic_line: I didn't build this, it was a living history exhibit run by U Amherst, modeled after old Norse structures and culture.  One of my buddies wanted to make it big in the re-enacting business, so they took an internship here.  I was planning on getting in to it with them as a tour guide, but <the_cataclysm> put a stop to it.  We came here from town, found the place wasn't occupied by those horrors, and set up camp here.  My friend must've thought that the old legends he'd studied had some meaning in them, and convinced the rest of us that we should start following them. We found large group fleeing one of those FEMA camps when we went out for food, and he convinced them to join us.

responses.text: How did you come to power here?
I'd like to ask you about something else.

dynamic_line: A friend of mine lead the operation before I did.  They were really interested in Norse mythology, almost obsessed with it, and found some meaning in the old proverbs and practices.  After <the_cataclysm>, they started preaching to a group who ran from town, and convinced them that the old ways should be followed again.  I came along, not wanting to abandon them in the wilderness or forsake my friends and their message.

responses.text: I'd like to ask you about something else.

dynamic_line: We were out on another routine scavenging run one day, like we'd done many times before.  Some horde followed us out of town, and we had to fight them off along a tree line.  Something was off about this one <zombie> though, huge and burly towards the back.  We managed to handle the rest of them easy, but this one guy was a bit much for the three of usâ€¦

responses.text: I'm guessing that didn't go well.

dynamic_line: *has a flash of sadness cross their face, hanging their head down.*  "I'm sorry, I couldn't save them.  They all died to that horrid monster.  I buried all three of them, and was chosen to rule by a will one of them left.  I realized then that my friend was right; only the strong survive, and only the strong live long enough to enjoy that.  So the old ways teach.

responses.text: I'm sorry for your loss.  I'd like to ask you about something else.
I'm sorry for your loss, I should get going.
